title: Getting Started with GeoLightViz
text: GeoLightViz interactive Shiny application designed streamline analysis geolocator light data. provides intuitive interface visualizing labeling twilight events (sunrise/sunset times) simultaneously displaying geographic positions interactive map. tutorial demonstrates two-step workflow using data European Bee-eater (tag ID: 14OI) tagged Germany: Step 1: Label twilight events define stationary periods (equipment/retrieval sites) Step 2: Generate likelihood maps refine position estimates

title: Getting Started with GeoLightViz

title: Getting Started with GeoLightViz
text: first step load geolocator data using tag_create() function GeoPressureR package. function reads raw light measurements structures standardized format. Key parameters: - crop_start crop_end: Define analysis period, excluding irrelevant data deployment retrieval - assert_pressure = FALSE: Required light-geolocators without atmospheric pressure sensors resulting tag object contains: - Light data: Cropped specified date range - Twilight events: Automatically detected sunrise sunset times
code: tag <- tag_create(   "14OI",   directory = file.path(extdata_dir, "data/raw-tag/14OI"),   crop_start = "2015-08-09",   crop_end = "2016-07-11",   assert_pressure = FALSE )  # Detect twilight events tag <- twilight_create(tag)  # View the tag structure tag

title: Getting Started with GeoLightViz
text: Define geographic extent resolution likelihood map calculations: Parameters explained: - extent: Geographic bounding box [west, east, south, north] decimal degrees - Defines area bird potentially traveled - encompass known breeding, migration, wintering regions - scale: Grid resolution (higher = finer detail, slower computation) - scale = 1: ~111 km grid cells (fast, suitable initial exploration) - scale = 5: ~22 km grid cells (detailed, used European Bee-eater)

title: GeoLightViz: Interactive Visualization Tool for Light-Level Geolocator Analysis — GeoLightViz-package
text: Provides interactive Shiny application exploring understanding light-level geolocator data analysis. app features unique side--side visualization shows twilight events (sunrise/sunset times) translate geographic positions map real-time. Users can interactively label twilight data, define stationary periods, test position hypotheses clicking map, explore calibration effects likelihood surfaces. Designed make complex twilight geolocation method transparent intuitive, helping researchers understand data quality, position uncertainty, role calibration improving estimates.
